description: Imperial Nostalgia & the Built Environment –  A thought-provoking keynote address followed by a panel discussion exploring the theme of imperial nostalgia in the built environment, using Wembley as a case study.

events.name: Decolonising Wembley Key Note and Panel Discussion

factsheet.heading: Nabil Al-Kinani's Guest Curator Event 2023
paragraphs: Nabil Al-Kinani is a British-Iraqi built-environment professional and creative practitioner raised in Wembley, he possesses a keen interest in urbanism, cultural placemaking, sustainable development and spatial politics. His research largely focuses on “spaces” and “stories”. Addressing questions such as: Who designs space? Who has access to newly-created space? What’s the cultural impact of these newly-created spaces? Who are new spaces being built for? Who is affected by newly-created space? What are the narratives that must be preserved when new spaces are being created?
His works include: Authors of the Estate, Privatise the Mandem and Pipe Dreams.

factsheet.heading: Decolonising Wembley
paragraphs: Imperial Nostalgia & the Built Environment –  A thought-provoking keynote address followed by a panel discussion exploring the theme of imperial nostalgia in the built environment, using Wembley as a case study. Delve into the history and cultural significance of this piece of London and examine the ways in which it reflects our changing attitudes towards empire and colonialism. This event creates an opportunity to gain insight into one of the most fascinating and controversial topics in modern architecture and design.

factsheet.heading: Panellists
paragraphs:
Alistair Napier,
Nathan Quainoo,
Joanna Oyediran, 
Kevin Manton,
Alison Bennett,
Moderated by: Hafsa Adan

travel_info: Train: Euston, City Thameslink, Charing Cross

name: Decolonising Wembley
